The Laffer Curve suggests that it is possible to cut taxes while increasing revenues. This in fact happened during the 1980s.
 
 Unfortunately there has never yet been an economy that can tax more than the government can spend.
 
 Surpluses emerge from time to time, usually the result of unexpected economic gains.
 
 These are then frittered away with even more social programs which, once the economy slows down, act as a further drag on the balance books.
 
 One of the things that interests me about these debates are how they ignore the examples of US states, all of whom have their own budgets and who provide the bulk of services to most US citizens.
 
 States that keep their books in balance do better than those that don't. When surpluses flow in, smart states offer rebate checks or tax cuts. Foolish states simply create new entitlements.
 
 Then, when recession strikes, the state is forced to raise taxes to cover the the drop in revenue.
 
 The end result: A steadily eroding tax base as the most productive businesses and residents leave for more competitive areas.
 
 This can be seen in a microcosm in many major cities. Lansing, for example, levies a 1 percent income tax (.5 percent if you work there, .5 percent if you live there, 1 percent if both).
 
 This is a huge incentive for businesses to move out, since they are also paying higher property taxes by being in the city.
 
 So the wealthy do what their interests tell them to do: Move 1 mile away where they can avoid thousands of dollars in taxes and receive often superior services.
